name: Silver Pheasant
description: The male is black and white, while the female is brown. Both have red facial wattles and red legs.
food_note: Seeds, shoots, and other plant parts, invertebrates
image_alt: Silver pheasant, photo: Tereza Mrhálková, Prague Zoo
proportions: Body length 70–125 cm, with the male's tail up to 75 cm; weight 1.1–2 kg
reproduction: Females lay 6–15 eggs and incubate them for 26–27 days.
attractions: It is very hardy, breeds well, and often both parents care for the chicks. In Chinese art, it appears as the so-called white phoenix. Its low-maintenance nature and attractive appearance make it highly popular among private breeders.
breeding: The silver pheasant is a relatively new species at Prague Zoo. We have kept the nominate subspecies (L. n. nycthemera) since 2006. Since 2012, a pair of the rarer Chinese-Thai subspecies, Jones's silver pheasant (L. n. jonesi), has been added, found from Myanmar to southwestern China and central Thailand. Besides Prague Zoo, only two other European zoos keep this subspecies.
